text: other hand, retail investors who predominantly use simple strategies do not appear to learn from their lack of success. When using their dominant simple strategies, they significantly underperform the benchmark by −0.097 (t-stat = −186.3) on average. They generally show higher returns when using other strategies (coefficient = 0.074, t-stat = 133.5), but they fail to change their trading style and instead adhere to the losing style. These results indicate that retail investors using simple strategies are less likely to behave as Bayesian learners, while institutional investors and retail volatility traders exhibit a higher level of sophistication when choosing their dominant trading style. This further confirms the utility of the trading styles in measuring investor sophistication, especially in the case of retail traders. [Table 11 about here] 5.3. Trading Styles and Behavioral Biases One of our primary observations, which appears across all analyses, is that retail investors who use simple strategies lose to the rest of the market. Given the predominance of this trading style among retail investors, we explore in this section possible causes of the underperformance by retail simple strategy traders. We start by examining whether the choice of dominant strategy by retail investors corresponds to known behavioral biases. Underperformance due to biases may be amplified in the options market due to the high leverage and fat tail risk embedded in option contracts. Using each account’s activity and performance measures, we construct account-level proxies for the five behavioral biases that are among the most well-known in the literature. First, Barber and Odean (2000) argue that retail investors’ overconfidence causes them to trade excessively, which is detrimental to their investment performance. To capture excessive trading activity, we calculate the logarithm of the average daily options trading volume of each retail account as a measure of investor overconfidence. Second, Odean (1998) shows a disposition effect in which retail investors will close winning positions early but hold on to losing positions for too long. Following his method, we measure disposition effect as an account’s proportion of gains realized (PGR) minus proportion of losses realized (PLR). On a given day, PGR is the total number of contracts with realized gains (positions closed at a gain) divided by that number plus the total number of contracts with paper gains (open positions which have increased in value from the previous day). PLR is calculated similarly. Then, we sum the daily values over the sample period and take the difference of PGR and PLR.20 20 Disposition effect is equal to zero for day traders as they close all of their positions before the end of the trading day. 26 Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3867129

text: Third, some investors may exhibit a demand for options with lottery‐like payoffs (see e.g., Boyer and Vorkink, 2014), which have a low probability of being profitable. We measure lottery preference as the out-of-the-money (OTM) option contracts bought by an account. In the case of position holders, this refers to the percentage of positions that are in long OTM contracts; in the case of day traders, it refers to the percentage of opening intraday trades that buy OTM contracts. Fourth, retail investors may be prone to making investment decisions following trends. We capture trend-chasing behavior, also known as extrapolation or positive feedback trading (see e.g., De Long et al., 1990; Li et al., 2021), by calculating the sensitivity of an investor’s delta exposure to KOSPI 200 index returns. This is derived by regressing each account’s end-of-day position delta (for position holders) or the volume-weighted average delta of opening intraday trades (for day traders) on past five- day average index return. Fifth, we measure self-attribution bias (Gervais and Odean, 2001; Hoffmann and Post, 2014) which is defined as investors’ belief that past success is due to skill rather than luck. In other words, profitable investors assume they will continue to be profitable in the future and consequently increase their market activity. We calculate the sensitivity of investor activity to past performance by regressing position size (for position holders) or intraday trading volume (for day traders) on past five-day average return of the investor. In addition to the five bias proxies above, we include two further variables as controls for other factors which may affect investor performance. The first is a proxy for transaction costs and is equal to the percentage of each account’s trading volume that is initiated. The second is a dummy variable equal to one if the account is a foreign investor, as per studies on the outperformance of foreign investors (e.g., Grinblatt and Keloharju, 2000). In Table 12, we perform logistic regressions for the probability of retail investors to use a particular trading style given the behavioral bias proxies. We find that the likelihood of retail investors to use simple strategies as their dominant trading style is positively and significantly associated with the proxies for investor overconfidence (coefficient = 0.034, t-stat = 7.79), disposition effect (coefficient = 0.868, t-stat = 25.8), and lottery preference (coefficient = 2.267, t-stat = 87.14). The same investors strongly prefer to provide rather than take liquidity (coefficient on % of volume initiated = −0.978, t- stat = −33.06) and they do not tend to chase trends. We find contrasting results for retail investors whose dominant trading style consists of complex strategies. In particular, the likelihood of retail investors to use volatility trading strategies as their dominant style is negatively and significantly associated with the proxies for overconfidence (coefficient = −0.124, t-stat = −13.36), disposition effect (coefficient = −0.314, t-stat = −4.48), and lottery preference (coefficient = −3.876, t-stat = −48.85). Similarly, the likelihood of retail investors to use Greek neutral strategies as their dominant style is also significantly negatively associated with the proxies for disposition effect (coefficient = −0.954, t-stat = −10.28), and 27 Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3867129

text: lottery preference (coefficient = −0.416, t-stat = −5.98). One exception is the observed high average daily trading volume of Greek neutral traders, but this observation can be a feature of the strategy itself rather than a sign of overconfidence. We do not find self-attribution bias to affect the strategies chosen by any of the retail investors that we examine. Our analysis also reveals that foreign retail investors are less likely to use simple strategies. Overall, we find that behavioral bias measures for overconfidence, disposition effect, and lottery preference are significantly associated with the level of complexity of an account’s trading style. [Table 12 about here] In our final analysis in Table 13, we investigate whether the behavioral biases drive the previously identified effects of trading style on investor profitability. The literature posits that these biases can have direct channels to affecting performance; therefore, we include their proxies as control variables in the performance analysis regressions. We find that the behavior of the dominant strategy dummies generally conforms to the previous findings. Although the results are consistent with the literature in showing that many of the behavioral biases adversely affect retail investor performance, the trading style effects remain strongly significant and do not appear to be driven by the biases. This suggests a separate venue for trading styles to impact performance through investor (un)sophistication rooted in yet unidentified psychological reasons. [Table 13 about here] 6. Conclusion Despite growing trading volumes in derivatives markets worldwide, little is known about the trading activities of option investors at the account level. In this study, we analyze a comprehensive data set of account-level transactions in KOSPI 200 index options and futures in order to investigate the profitability of option trading strategies employed by different types of investors. Our study contributes to the literature by casting new light on the most popular motivations for trading options and thereby uncovering a measure of investor sophistication, which exceeds the traditional classification by investor class. Specifically, we propose the complexity of an investor’s dominant trading strategy as an ex ante measure of trading skill and show its significant effect on investment outcomes. We start by investigating the application of common option trading strategies. We find that simple option strategies, which provide directional exposure to the underlying asset, are widely used by retail investors. A portion of institutional investors also use simple strategies to take directional bets, but the majority of institutions are skilled at using various complex strategies. We show that both institutional and retail investors apply volatility trading more often than the other classic options 28 Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3867129
title: Who Profits From Trading Options 20210614
author: jianfenghu

text: investors. A portion of institutional investors also use simple strategies to take directional bets, but the majority of institutions are skilled at using various complex strategies. We show that both institutional and retail investors apply volatility trading more often than the other classic options 28 Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3867129 strategies. We also uncover a small number of accounts, both institutional and retail, which generate large trading volumes using sophisticated and well-hedged positions. After uncovering the most popular options strategies used by different investors, we proceed to examine account performance. Although we find that investor class affects profitability and institutions generally outperform retail investors, we ultimately show that trading style complexity has an additional and even stronger effect on performance. Within each of the investor classes, and especially concerning retail investors, the complexity of an account’s dominant strategy is significantly associated with investment performance. Investors using sophisticated strategies such as volatility and Greek neutral strategies outperform their peers. In particular, volatility trading is the most profitable strategy in terms of average returns, and Greek neutral strategies deliver superior risk-return efficiency as measured by the Sharpe ratio. Meanwhile, we find that retail investors who use simple strategies lose to the rest of the market. Finally, we provide evidence that these trading style effects are persistent and cannot be explained by risk premiums or known behavioral biases, thereby positing a novel channel for investor sophistication to manifest in financial markets. These trading style effects may exist in other financial markets and enable investors to explore various trading strategies. Examining the additional style effects in other markets would be a valuable line of research for future studies. 29 Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3867129

text: Table 5 Summary Statistics of Account Profitability This table reports the cross-sectional means and percentiles of three different profitability measures. We look at 122,620 active accounts that trade options. First, for each account, we use the transactions records to calculate the total cumulative profit and loss ($P&L) over the whole sample period from January 1, 2010 to June 30, 2014. We use the contract multiplier to calculate profits in Korean won (KRW) and we report total account $P&L in millions of KRW. Then, for each account and each trading day, we calculate profitability per dollar as: Daily return (cid:3404) Total daily $P&L / Total daily capital requirement (cid:4666) $P&L from end-of-day positions (cid:3397) $P&L from intraday trades (cid:4667) (cid:3404) . (cid:4666) Lag of end-of-day capital requirement (cid:3397) Intraday capital requirement (cid:4667) Refer to Section 4 for additional details regarding our method for calculating daily returns. This scaled P&L measure is a rate of return to each dollar of capital invested in KOSPI derivatives. To have one single return measure for each account, we take the mean of daily returns of the same account during the whole sample period. We also calculate Sharpe ratio of each account as the mean daily return divided by the standard deviation of daily returns. Panel A shows account profitability of institutions versus retail investors and Panel B shows the profitability by trading style. text: Table 6 Profitability of the Different Investor Accounts: Regression analyses This table presents multivariate regression analyses of the relation between account profitability and investor types. We include the 122,620 active accounts that trade options. We perform six account-level regressions. Regressions 1, 2, 3 use mean daily return as the dependent variable, and regressions 4, 5, 6 use the Sharpe ratio. The independent variable in regressions 1 and 4 is a dummy variable for institutional investors, and the intercept represents retail investors. The independent variables in regressions 2 and 5 are the trading style dummies for day traders, simple strategy traders, volatility traders and Greek neutral traders, and the intercept represents the remaining accounts in the category “Others”. Regressions 3 and 6 use the investor class dummy and the trading style dummies at the same time. The table contains the estimated regression coefficients and below them the corresponding t-statistics in parentheses. ***, **, and * indicate statistical significance at the 1%, 5%, and 10% levels, respectively. The sample time period is from January 1, 2010 to June 30, 2014. text: Table 7 Robustness Checks We repeat the profitability regressions of Table 6 using alternative definitions of dominant strategy and different measures of profitability. The dependent variable in regression 1 is risk-adjusted return, which for a given account is equal to the intercept from a time-series regression of the account's daily returns on the KOSPI 200 index returns and implied volatility. The daily implied volatility is calculated as the price-weighted average implied volatility of all ATM options, derived from the last daily transactions executed in the 15 minutes before market close. We also examine the t-statistic of the intercept and use it as the dependent variable in regression 2, as analogous to our analysis of Sharpe ratio. To prevent the effects of outliers in regressions 1 and 2, we winsorize the dependent variables cross-sectionally at 5% and 95%. The dependent variables in regressions 3 and 4 are mean daily return from positions and Sharpe ratio from positions. Here, we exclude position holders' intraday trading profits when calculating daily returns. For regressions 5 and 6, we define dominant strategies and calculate mean daily returns excluding any simple positions in short call and long put contracts, in order to exclude any possible hedges of unobserved equity positions. Regressions 7–10 show the results when dominant strategies are defined using different cutoff points. Finally, regression 11 reports the results of a pooled OLS regression in the panel using account-day observations instead of account-level. The independent variables in all regressions are the same as in Table 6. The table contains the estimated regression coefficients and below them the corresponding t-statistics in parentheses. ***, **, and * indicate statistical significance at the 1%, 5%, and 10% levels, respectively. The sample time period is from January 1, 2010 to June 30, 2014. 40 Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3867129

For example, Simple strategy trader using nondominant strategy is a dummy variable equal to 1 on days when a simple strategy trader holds positions in volatility, Greek neutral, or other strategies, and equal to 0 on days when the account holds simple positions. text: Table 12 Effect of Behavioral Biases on Retail Investors’ Trading Style This table reports logistic regressions for the probability of retail investors using a particular trading style given variables which are proxies for well-known behavioral biases potentially related to retail behavior and profitability. Trading volume refers to the logarithm of average daily options trading volume, which serves as a proxy for overconfidence or excessive trading. Disposition effect is measured as an account’s proportion of gains realized (PGR) minus proportion of losses realized (PLR). On a given day, PGR is the total number of contracts with realized gains (positions closed at a gain) divided by that number plus the total number of contracts with paper gains (open positions which have increased in value from the previous day). PLR is calculated similarly. Then, we sum the daily values over the sample time period, and we take the difference of PGR and PLR. (Disposition effect is 0 for day traders.) OTM contracts bought refers to the percentage of positions in long OTM contracts (for position holders) or the percentage of opening intraday trades buying OTM contracts (for day traders). This is a measure of lottery preference. Sensitivity of delta to KOSPI 200 index return is derived by regressing an account’s end-of-day position delta scaled by position size (for position holders), or the volume- weighted average delta of opening intraday trades (for day traders), on past five-day average index return. This is a proxy for trend chasing (extrapolation) behavior. Sensitivity of investor activity to performance is derived by regressing position size (for position holders) or intraday trading volume (for day traders) on past five-day average return of the investor. This is a proxy for self-attribution bias. The % of volume initiated is a proxy for transaction costs. Finally, we include a dummy equal to 1 if the account is a foreign investor. The table contains the estimated regression coefficients and below them the corresponding t-statistics in parentheses. ***, **, and * indicate statistical significance at the 1%, 5%, and 10% levels, respectively. The sample time period is from January 1, 2010 to June 30, 2014.
